term.title: Gibbs adsorption

item.text: The surface excess amount or Gibbs adsorption of component i, n i σ, which may be positive or negative, is defined as the excess of the amount of this component actually present in the system over that present in a reference system of the same volume as the real system and in which the bulk concentrations in the two phases remain uniform up to the Gibbs dividing surface. That is n i σ = n i- V α c i α- V β c is the total amount of the component i in the system, ciα and ciβ are the concentrations in the two bulk phases α and β, and V α and V β are the volumes of the two phases defined by the Gibbs surface.

item.alttext: n i σ = n i- V α c i α- V β c
